title: 113_s1843
content: The Act titled "Federal Information Technology Savings, Accountability, and Transparency Act of 2013" increases the authority of agency Chief Information Officers over information technology. The Act "Federal Information Technology Savings, Accountability, and Transparency Act of 2013" enhances the authority of agency Chief Information Officers by requiring their appointment or designation by the President within certain agencies listed in title 31. The Act "Federal Information Technology Savings, Accountability, and Transparency Act of 2013" mandates the appointment of agency Chief Information Officers by the President, based on demonstrated ability in information technology management. The CIOs report directly to the agency head and are responsible for specific duties outlined in the Act. The Act mandates the appointment of agency Chief Information Officers by the President. CIOs report directly to the agency head and have specific duties outlined in the Act. Title 44 designates CIOs under certain conditions, with additional authorities for certain CIOs related to budget and personnel. The Act mandates agency Chief Information Officers appointed by the President, with specific duties outlined. CIOs have authority in budget planning for information technology components. The Chief Information Officer of an agency, in consultation with the Chief Financial Officer and budget officials, must allocate funds for information technology products or services in accordance with appropriations Acts and budget guidelines. The Chief Information Officer of each agency, excluding the Department of Defense, must have authority over acquiring commercially available off-the-shelf IT products or services. They also have the authority to approve hiring personnel with IT responsibilities within the agency. Each agency must have a single Chief Information Officer who oversees IT responsibilities and personnel reporting structure. Subordinate organizations can designate a Deputy Chief Information Officer or Associate Chief Information Officer. The provision specifies the titles of `Deputy Chief Information Officer', `Associate Chief Information Officer', or `Assistant Chief Information Officer' and their effective date of October 1, 2014. Individuals in affected positions before this date can continue if they meet the requirements. The Chief Information Officers Council plays a lead coordination role. The Chief Information Officers Council is designated as the lead interagency forum for improving agency coordination of Federal Government information resources investment. It is responsible for developing cross-agency portfolio management practices to facilitate the development of shared services and platforms. The Chief Information Officers Council leads interagency coordination of Federal Government information resources investment, developing shared services and platforms. Guidelines and practices are issued for expanding the Federal enterprise architecture process, focusing on transparency, common inputs, outputs, and outcomes for performance comparison across diverse agency missions. Relevant congressional committees are defined. The Chief Information Officers Council leads interagency coordination of Federal Government information resources investment and develops shared services. Relevant congressional committees receive required reports summarizing the Council's activities and recommendations for further actions. The Chief Information Officers Council coordinates Federal Government information resources investment and develops shared services. The Council provides recommendations for further congressional action as needed. Amendments allow the Administrator to be referred to as the Federal Chief Information Officer. SEC. 4. REPORTS BY GOVERNMENT ACCOUNTABILITY OFFICE. The Chief Information Officers Council, as defined by section 3603(a) of title 44, United States Code, is examined for effectiveness by the Comptroller General of the United States. Relevant congressional committees include those in the Senate and House of Representatives. The Comptroller General examines the Chief Information Officers Council's effectiveness in meeting its responsibilities under section 3603(d) of title 44, United States Code. Reports are to be submitted to relevant congressional committees at 1 year, 3 years, and 5 years after enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. ENHANCED TRANSPARENCY IN INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY INVESTMENTS. Enhanced transparency in IT investments is mandated by making cost, schedule, and performance data for 80% of all IT investments in federal agencies publicly available. The Director or Chief Information Officer can waive or limit the information on IT investments if it is in the national security interests of the United States. The report requirements for information technology investments in a Federal agency under title 31 include an analysis of agency trends in performance risk information.
